In that language he had acquired suf- ficient facility, and he possessed, besides, the happy art (a) of giving grace and dig- nity to whatever he uttered. He inflamed the passions not only of the army, but also of the province, by asserting roundly," that it was a fixed point with Vitellius," to quarter the German troops in the de-*' lightful region of Syria, that, in a rich w and plentiful province, they might grow" wanton in ease and luxury; while, in ex-*' change, the legions of Syria were to be" removed to cold encampments in Ger-*' many, there to endure the inclemency" of the weather, and the rigours of the" service." The natives of the province had lived in habits of friendship with the legions, and, by intermarriages, had form- ed family connections. The soldiers, on their part, were naturalized in the country, and the stations, to which they were accus-. tomed, were, by long residence, grown as dear to them as their native home. LXXXI.
